We were there kinda early (7:30), so it was still pretty mellow and quiet, which was nice. Most importantly, the food came out really fast (we were starving). 
Our appetizer was the best part of the meal: roasted garlic, cambazola cheese, and a fig compote, all to be spread on grilled bread. Can't go wrong with that! For my main course, I got the prawns grilled with peppers, onions, and bacon, with a side of roasted vegetables, and a side of roasted potatoes. Although the food was tasty, it was missing some pizazz, it could have used a bit more seasoning. My sides were quite good, they potatoes and veggies tasted like they were roasted in butter, which I will never complain about.

Overall a satisfying meal, but not terribly impressed.
author: Kelly L.

description:
We stopped by here on a pub/bar crawl up from 24th st to 14th st or thereabouts  - so really this review is pretty limited to the one drink that we had here. But oh what a drink! We were serenaded by a insanely huge mariachi band that was GREAT. My companions were enamoured with their strong house margaritas...The atmosphere is totally fun!

I think I will definitely try the restaurant offerings soon---- gotta use up that restaurant.com coupon!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description: I love this place! I've been going for at least 3 years with my husband and some of his friends! Everytime I get the seafood stew along with 1 of their tostada de ceviche and sometimes the wings! Yes I like their food:) ..yumm!! The happy hour is very nice! $4 margaritas...Love it:)
author: Christine L.

description:
I wish I could dismiss this place as entirely forgettable, but sadly, i remember it far too clearly.  I have almost nothing good to say about it.

The service was friendly but rough around the edges -- drinks took forever to show up; my 7 companions complained about theirs being weak. (I ordered a manhattan, which was slightly too bitter, but really impossible to make weak.)  

But the most damning thing was that the food verged on terrible, particularly at that price range ($20 per main, $8 per appetizer / side). The bread was cold and its crust was soft; it tasted like those Italian batards that you can pick up at any produce mart or at Whole Foods. They gave us plates of olive oil for dipping, but with no vinegar, salt, pepper, or herbs, and there weren't even enough olive oil dishes for the table. 

The rest of the menu was sadly lacking. I'm [recently] vegan, and while I understand that it's a niche diet and I don't expect to eat lavishly at most restaurants in the city, I've always been able to cobble together a reasonably filling, nutritionally complete meal at most places. That said, this IS san francisco, and it's kind of annoying to go to a restaurant that clearly has not thought at ALL about its vegetarian / vegan customers. It only takes one bean dish and refraining from adding ham to the veggies, people.

At Cava 22, the only veggie options were fried glycemic carbs (empanadas with a dull corn filling; polenta sticks with tomato sauce; plantains with yogurt sauce;  and some of the most dreary french fries i've ever paid $8 for, mealy and soft without even the dignity of being greasy and salty). I tried them all and none were particularly good. 

I skipped the sauteed greens that were on the menu as side dishes.

I also ordered the one salad without cheese -- a mixed greens salad with almonds. (Hello? Perhaps some olives or roasted red peppers would be appropriate here?) It was almost inedible. Each leaf tasted as if it had been marinated in distilled vinegar. The whole thing was dreadfully oversalted. Had they applied the salt and vinegar to the french fries and left the damn salad alone, they may have come out ahead of the game, but alas. 

Even more tiresome: I ordered my 3 appetizer dishes. A few minutes later the waiter came back to point out that I had not ordered a main dish. I said that I didn't eat animal products. He asked had I seen the vegetarian options. I said yes, and that I had ordered three of them. He then got confused about what I had ordered and the person next to me had ordered (shrimp, oysters, and a different salad), and we each had to repeat our orders back to him twice. 

What a mess. The decor was trite; the cocktail menu was limited, unoriginal, and all over the map; and now I'm out $40 that I could have used to buy 10 infinitely more satisfying veggie burritos.
author: Ellen B.

description:
This place recently came up on Thrillist and I have a birthday group dinner to plan for my SO, so space for our 10-20person group is key
(Yeah it was one of those TBD evites, which has now firmed up :)
I did some quick recon (w/ iphone camera in hand, see pics hint hint) and Cava seems to fit the bill
Roger, the manager was very helpful in taking a reservation and mentioned they are changing the wine list for the better
The main dining area and bar is an entire corner and they've annexed another building next door for a separate, but attached dining area
I assume there is no absurd $4pp cake cutting charge like the much smaller and more $ Limon on Valencia (I even stopped by Limon and asked them to explain the cake charge, I couldn't believe they could even keep a smile on their face while they were basically saying FU)
There's also a Wells Fargo party on the same school night and the restaurant is open for regular business, we'll see how it all pans out

Bonus is there are a gazillion other places a bunnyhop, skip and jump around the corner if y'all feel the need to location bounce

*side note* evite's built in text editor mangles yelp urls when you try to put them in the event description, when  are the host/admin of the evite event, guess they dont want u going offsite, poo
author: G K.

description:
Haven't tried the food but for me, this is the spot to go to for drinks when all the other bars in the Mission have been taken over by the non-locals for the night. They have plenty of tequila options and friendly staff. It's a casual, low-key spot with lots of seating and quiet enough for you to carry a conversation with your pals over some drinks while watching the hipsters spill out on the sidewalk at Revolution across the street. Because some nights, you don't really want to be in a crowded bar but you still want to get your drink on.

This location is known to be cursed, so I hope Cava22 stays longer than the others have. This place has potential. They just gotta read Yelp and fix the kinks.
author: Zell C.

description:
I came here after driving around for an hour trying to find Herbivore's.  When we (male counterparts and myself) got to Valencia the restaurant was on fire.   Seriously.   We wandered around and somehow wound up in Cava 22 because it looked a little less scary than the place across which was full of hipster parents with their toddlers and old people.  There was a jazz trio playing.

Anyway, when we walked in we were greeted right away, good service.  I believe Shakira was playing, bonus points because I know that "Hips Don't Lie" is STILL my favorite song.

We were seated right away.  I'm sure it had nothing to do with the fact that NO ONE was there at 4 pm on a Sunday afternoon, (who doesn't want to drink expensive tequila at 4pm on Sunday?)

My dear friend James proceeded to order 3 shots of $20 dollar tequila.  When the server brought them over he put one in front of each of us.  I started to move the shot towards James, I assumed he had bought the 3 shots for himself.  (He's been drinking a lot lately.)  He kindly handed the shot back to me.  sweet.    The shots came with these little citrus-y bloody Mary type chasers.   I also had a margarita, another shot, and something that was on the house that also had tequila in it.  All drinks were superb and might I add that their restrooms are very nice.

I ordered a Greek salad, we had some tapas thingies, James and Nick ate salmon or something like that.  Everything was damn good and our server was awesome.  He was from Chile and I found out that the Andes are in Chile and it is a coastal country!  Who knew!

It was an incredibly bromantical dinner.
author: Mimi V.

description: This is the ideal spot for a Happy Hour gathering with staff and/or friends. Tasty and affordable drinks, killer nachos (not on the menu, but they'll whip 'um up!) and there's a jukebox that makes you feel like you can run the joint (or at least choose the  music!) The staff always makes our staff feel like home when we come by on a Friday afternoon. Thanks, CAVA!
author: Amy Grace C.

description:
I was touched by the sincerity of the woman who seated us, telling us that the food options were her venture...I can tell everyone that she means well.

That being said, in a city where oysters are some of the best and the tightest, do NOT sell them unless they shine.  And do NOT serve them with a miss for a mignonette and nothing else to cover up their lack of...well, edibility.

The fries - must be frozen.  Cooked to perfection...for frozen fries.  Our salad was good, but not memorable.  We enjoyed the mushroom ravioli - the truffle oil was a surprise and was used well.

Drinks are pricey, that is true.  And for the lack of buzz after 3 on an awkward-ish date...

If the prices were muuuuch lower, I would return to eat with my shots of tequila, but sadly, I doubt it.  Too many other options on the same street that get the job done.

The oysters...those made me a little bit angry.  The bread without pepper for that fancy olive oil....made me a little sad.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Cava 22 gets three stars because it's a place that has so much potential and just hasn't lived up to it yet!!! 

It's an amazing space, and the drinks are fantastic. The food was so-so, but I think this place has amazing potential as a bar, not a restaurant. There's high ceilings and plenty of room for a stage and a dance floor. 

Keep the tequila, ditch the food, and give me a dancing spot close to home, Cava 22!!!
author: Nissa A.

description:
Haven't actually taken time to 'eat, drink and be merry' here - so many restaurants, so little time..but will stop by just to say hi to Amado. No way to count the number of times over the decades that he has helped me get soused and stumbling. LA RONDALLA is gonna re-open soon, hope he comes home.
VIVA BAJONES.
author: Patrick M.

description: First time to this place was 12/13/11 and since then this has been my #1 spot to pre-game before the night at the club or just come to SF for some great tequila. For me, the service is always spot on and and the food has been none less than delicious along with the great variety of music that could range from Latin music to main stream Hip-Hop. Simply put, I love this place!
author: Jor-El M.

description:
ok so let me say that this place is off the beaten track a bit, i say a bit because it is still in the heart of the mission. basically it is a perfect combination of a mexican restaurant and a bar. The only difference is that the mexican restaurant aspect of the place is somewhat high end without the prices. I work as a chef around the corner and i can definately say they use very high end high quality ingredients such as fresh watercress, aioli, porcini mushrooms and what is i am sure a wide array of quality organic product.

just the other day i found out there is some connection to La Rondalla, they either have the same bartender or chefs or something which is excellent in my book.

go here during happy hour for 4 dollar margaritas it will make you smile
author: Sean B.

description:
La Rondalla's drinks live on....
I heart you Armando.
author: Dario B.

description:
This is the kind of place that makes me want to cry. Nice people with good intentions but the place just seems to miss the point in terms of the decor, layout, food, heat, and service.

The guy running the place is really friendly. We were perusing the menu outside, and he came out and offered us free margaritas if we came in and ate there. 
The margaritas were really good. The staff seemed a little confused, but on the whole were pretty good.
But....
1)The place was FREEZING. It would've been close to 36 degrees in there. Maybe this is because the space is so large.
2) The food was ok. The bacon infused salad dressing on the spinach salad was an interesting choice but was really really killer salty.
3) We never got served the bottle of wine we ordered.
So we ate as quick as we could and got the hell outta there, heading for a warm toasty drinking spot to thaw out in.
author: MissSkip Z.

description: Ok. So my husband and I were in the mood for some Mariachi and Tequila...the Mariachi was good, no problem there, but when I get served my shot of Añejo Tequila.....it burned like ALCOHOL!! Come on, I know my tequilas, and that certainly was not what I ordered, I told our waitress and she came back with the bottle....you know what, I don't care if she poured it straight from the bottle! That was not añejo tequila! So beware, unless u are in L.A. or Mexico, you are probably not drinking the real thing!!!!! Remember an Añejo Tequila should not burn, its actually very smooth, no burn and also "should" be an amber color. I give it two stars, only for the Mariachi.......sorry, enjoying a good mariachi usually has to be accompanied by a good añejo tequila, not to pound but to sip and enjoy!!!!!!!
author: Jeanette P.

description:
Reviewed for drinks/service only.
This was the Second (out of 3) stop for Boom Dizzle's Bday.  
The Good:
1)  Friendly Service
2)  Tequila based drinks were mixed/made well
3)  Very spacious venue

The Bad:
1)  Did not notice anything bad about the place while I was there....

The Ugly:
1)  Bracing ourselves for the Dragon Bar in North Beach.....
author: ronzilla x.

description:
I know you've been walking by this big, empty place that replaced big, empty Bahia and wondering how they stay in business.  Fiance and I decided to investigate a few weeks ago...and aren't really sure (but we enjoyed our drinks).

There were mariachi, very good mariachi.  Unfortunately, my date has tinnitus and tinnitus + loud trumpets = pain.  Also, I didn't have any thing smaller than a twenty and I felt guilty for not giving them any money.

The drinks are surprisingly good.  I had a granadita (pomegranate infused tequila with pomegranate juice) and it was delicious.  The appetizers are tasty as well - we had a Cambazola plate with toasted bread and roasted garlic, along with fried plantains.  The plantains were coated in cinnamon, which left them a little dusty.

Dinner was boring.   I had camarones al mojo de ajo, which weirdly involved a tomato sauce (I'm thinking it was the wrong order).  The shrimp were uninteresting, the rice Uncle Ben's, but the beans were pretty tasty.  Fiance's milanesa was passable.

We'll go back for margaritas and snacks, but eat dinner at home.
author: Michelle S.

description: wow, much better food! i dont know what they did in the kitchen, but everything was fresh, on time and really good! way to step it up c22!
author: Roy N.

description: I have been here enough times now to say that I really do like it. Their chips & salsa are awesome (they bring you some even if you just order drinks, which is a big plus.) The food, namely the fish tacos and the camarones al mojo de ajo, is quite good, and comes with two sides of your choice, enough to share with a friend ($12-$13 range). It's a fun, big space close to other hot spots. Also almost every time i've been by on a weekend, a full-on 10 piece mariachi band came inside and played!
author: Shannon R.

description: Mixed bag.  Our server was slack, and distracted, while the table next to us had great service.  Happy hour maragarita prices are a winner, but I doubt I'll be back.
author: Lauren M.

description: Across from a parking garage (major bonus in the Mission), friendly crowd, fun atmosphere, consistent food and strong drinks.  Always a good time!
author: Rachel T.

description:
So my cousin had her bday party there, and I believe the poor guy didn't realize she was having a "party".  The staff was so overwhelmed. When it was last call...they were relieved, and basically scooted us out..so if u decide to have a party there, pls warn the manager, so he can have more staff, other than that, it was cool!
Parking sucks though...but that's the norm..
author: Iris G.

description:
Just moved to the Mission and thought I'd check out some of the local fare.  Stumbled upon Cava-22 and decided to give it a try.  Huge space with lots of dark wood, very empty on a Monday night...which was fine by me.  Our server was very polite and fast (again, we were one of 2 tables dining - so I can't say that's representative of the restaurant on a busy night).  We ordered a bottle of Merlot - actually we ordered Cabernet, but they brought Merlot - not a big deal.  Nice wine, reasonably priced.  

Tried the empanadas - very tasty.  I ordered the beef fajitas and the bf ordered the 3 enchilada combo.  Huge portion, delicious refried beans, nicely spiced.   Very filling!  Total bill $65.00 with tip - rather reasonable.  Worth a try if you're in the neighborhood, but wouldn't go out of my way....
author: Alison L.

description: While visiting a friend in SF we had a serious craving for oysters after hiking the lands end trail, so we popped into this place and found exactly what we were looking for. We ordered a dozen oysters on the half shell served with lime wedges, a pico de gallo and tapatio. YUM. The oysters were delicious and paired with a super yummy margarita. They also served us chips and super spicy salsa. Pretty much can't ask for more on a sunny saturday afternoon in the city.
author: Laura L.

description:
This restaurant itself is very appealing and caught my eye. I was with a group of friends and we decided to stop in here for some drinks after dinner. The drinks here are pretty cheap because they use house liquor, which is fine with me. They serve beer as cheap as three dollars and mixed drinks as expensive as nine dollars. I think that each person I was with had some sort of a margarita, which were all six dollars. I am a huge fan of good margaritas and decided on the blended strawberry margarita. I personally thought that mine could have been a little bit stronger and although it was good it tasted sort of like strawberry fruit snacks. Kind of weird, but tasty. My boyfriend ordered the blue agave and thought that it was very good and strong. 

I don't know if our waitress was new, but she seemed a little bit confused or lost. She was also very quiet which didn't help once the mariachi band started playing. 

Although it was fun to listen to the mariachi band play because the players are very talented, it was way too loud for such a small restaurant. By the second round of the mariachi band we decided to leave because it was too much for us.
author: Carly W.

description: I came here for a company party where the food was catered and the free drinks were flowing! The chicken tacos were to die for! There was plenty of beer on tap, but the drink of choice during the celebration was margaritas. I would definitely come back here with a group of friends, but mostly just to watch the extremely drunk guy being held up by his not so sober wife. I was making bets on them falling over, (un)fortunately they didn't.
author: Casi C.

description:
Well, this was kind of one big happenstance, as we only went into this place to use the bathroom and had no intentions of ordering drinks in the first place. But, being that we spyed the "Bathroom for Customers ONLY" sign, we felt morally obligated to pull over at the bar. Bad idea.

They've got a huge selection of tequila, including Los Osunas, which I have not seen in the States until now (it's one of the better tequilas I've smuggled across the border). But don't dare try any of the margaritas; they're like opening a glow stick and trying to drink it. They're extremely sweet, followed by extreme sour and virtually no hint of tequila. I couldn't finish mine and handed it off to poor boyfriend, who had just choked down a strawberry rita. 

Also, I'm pretty sure the waitress at the bar was tanked. Her eyes were rolling all over the place and she was all raspy sounding - I think she had had her fill of ritas.

Long story short, unless you're desperately trying to expand your tequila knowledge, steer clear.
author: Cheryl J.

description:
Ditto- Found it via Thrillist; almost too cold to take a layer off; not crowded... but the service was fantastic and the food was dish-lish.  They've got  good selection of tequila and a good margarita menu, though the one my friend tried was on the sweet side.  He had the short ribs (OMG, falling off the bone, delicious sauce...) and I had the game hen, which was a little... what's the word?  Not meaty.  But savory and with a good amount of vegetables and roasted potatoes that were perfection.

I was on the fence about the musician.  He was good, he was passionate and had a good repertoire... I think it was the sparse crowd that made him anything but charming.
author: Ani T.

description: Good empanadas, oysters. Came here for Cinco de Mayo which was a hoot. The food was OK but not too bad.
author: Eric R.

description:
Stopped in for some tapas and a drink and since it wasn't crowed we got to sit down right away. The service was good though slightly slow for how many people weren't there. 

For food we got a heaping portion of the pork though it was a little over salted which also contributed to it being on the drier side. Our other dish, prawns, were good however the prawns they were a little crispy and a little bland.

All in all it was a good experience, not the best but certainly not the worst. I think this place has a lot of potential to do well and that's why I gave it 4 stars. Let's just hope they read yelp!
author: Madeline T.

description:
One of my favorite places. It's on my list of places in what I call the Wild, Wild West. (check out website: vignettesfromtheendoftheline.blogspot.com)
Drinks are great, atmosphere always friendly, food good. What more can you ask for but some mariachis who play on Thursday and Saturdays!
author: MARGARITA V.

description:
Cava 22 is a great place whether for drinks or food.

They offer latin and spanish cuisine, such as fajtas,paiya, cevice etc.

The portions are huge, so you definitly get satisfied.

The prices are fair.

Chips, and salsa and fresh bread & butter are served.

My entrees I recommed include the seafood paiya, the cesar salad,
and the grilled skirt steak.

I had to give 4 stars as my calmari was to tough, and the batter was flaky that it came off the calamri.

The skirt steak was litle tough, but excellent taste. 

The staff is very friendly, I would definitly go back again.
author: Robert S.

description: Fish tacos....mmmm not so good. I expect the fish in fish tacos to fried and this was more like fish stew on tortillas. I did like the guac, the roasted garlic plate, and the watermelon margarita. It's a fun amosphere, with a cool young vibe.
author: Tiffany N.

description: I want to come back for their Happy Hour, where their margaritas are JUST $4. Best damn margaritas I've had in a long time! Maybe b/c it was Friday, but it washed away the dirt on my soul from having to smile at people I deplore in the workplace. (There's at least one.) It shed me of the weight of the 9-to-5-me and filled me with the light of 5-to-midnight-me. Yay-a! They use real watermelon juice for their Watermelon Margarita, and probably real strawberries for their Strawberry Margarita. Good stuff.
author: Nga H.

description: We found Cava 22 after wandering aimlessly through the pouring rain in the mission. The crowd was nice, it wasn't too stuffy and the prices were reasonable. They were having happy hour, with $4 margaritas and $3 drafts, I opted for a few watermelon margaritas. However, the highlight of this place was definitely the oysters. They were the freshest, lightest oysters I have tasted. They are served with a Mexican flair with limes, tapatio and a mignonette, which was more like a delicious watery salsa. I love oysters, and was happy that these were the first experience that my friend had with the seafood. We loved them so much we ended up getting three half orders.  I definitely recommend giving them a try I know I will be back.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
I made the mistake of choosing to go to this restaurant without reading the reviews. I noticed on Yelp that this establishment was in the Latin American category and was really in the mood for delicious cuisine. Imagine my disappointment when we arrived at the place and it turned out to be a bar and a semi-restaurant. The majority of the wooden tables were long, rectangular, and picnic style. However, they do have regular sized tables for smaller parties.

I ordered the Tostada de Ceviche. It was served as ceviche on top of avocado slices on top of a flat, hard tortilla shell. There was a little too much lime on this dish for me. I didn't think that there was anything special about this dish. The Platano Frito was interesting. I've never had fried plantain served with a side of sour cream before. It was served as an appetizer but since the plantains were covered in cinnamon and sugar, I feel that it's more appropriate as a dessert or a snack by itself. For my entree, I had the Seafood Paella. I did not like this dish at all. It was under-seasoned with the mussels and clams being overcooked. The rice was also soupy. 

As a restaurant, I don't recommend this place at all. I would say that it's more of a drinks and snacks place and because I was there mainly for dinner, I can't say anything about that aspect of the establishment.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Try the chili lime prawn dinner; I got mine with their black beans and rice on the side. Oh, and back that up with their strawberry margarita and call it a night!  Drink, dinner, tax, and tip came to $25.

The only drawback I would say is that the waiter seemed to be flying solo that night...so slow service on that end.  But yes, I am definitely going back.
author: Sara O.

description: This place is full of drunken douches. Irritating yuppies come here from the south bay, spending way too much money to get drunk. One time in July I almost got hit by a flying iPhone some douchebag threw around.
author: Carol C.

description:
Went to this restaurant on a Thursday night. The food was really good-plantains, shrimp, and roasted garlic with a fig compote... yummy!

The place has high ceilings so it gets pretty noisy but the maraichi band that arrived as we were leaving was very entertaining for the few minutes that we heard them.

Service was slow but it might have just been a bad night for them.

All in all a good time was had by all.
author: Dana L.

description: worst meal I've had in a long time. A few friends and I came here to split some small plates before going out. The waitress pretty much forgot about us and my friend had to get up and ask for water refills and if we could order. When the food did come it was basically inedible. The chicken fingers that came with fries were cold and hard, the fried calamari tasted like rubber and could hardly be chewed, and the chicken in the cheese enchiladas tasted as if it had been sitting around all day. There was nothing redeemable about this meal or our experience. I would highly suggest looking for somewhere else to dine.
author: Erica G.

description:
ahhh....that is NOT fernet!

dude it tastes like maple syrup.

two stars for lovely bathrooms
author: Alex P.

description: Great food, good atmosphere, huge selection of tequila, plenty of space for a large group. The BEST part is the mariachi band that comes in on the weekends. It's so much fun! I highly recommend it if you have a large group. it's never really too crowded. i hope it stays in business. it doesn't quite fit in with the white Valencia st. hipster. More of a Latino hangout. So it might not make it in that nook of the mission. but who knows...
author: Sanjay G.

description: Great Atmosphere for a drinks, apetizers and good convo with friends. Staff is very attentive and enjoyed the big screen TVs for sporting events. Highly recommend!
author: Edward B.

description: I came here for happy hour too.  They had really good strawberry margaritas.  But if you don't sit at the bar, the waitress will take a long time.  I haven't tried the food.
author: Sabrina A.

description: These folks have put a lot of effort into the place, but it is not quite there. We were there at an odd time and it was deserted, although other places in the neighborhood were full . It was nice that we could get all 10 around a big table, and the tables, paint, and fixtures are nice. Overall, the space just seems huge and empty, which I might not have noticed if it hadn't been INCREDIBLY COLD inside. I was freezing with my coat on, colder than outside even. The food was pretty good but arrived lukewarm even though we were the only people in the restaurant, I guess because it was so damn cold inside. The service was nice and attentive. The waiter explained that it is Spanish-French food but that didn't really explain the plantains with tzatziki.
author: Amy E.

description:
While this place is an improvement over the mexican seafood restaurant it replaced, it still has lots of work to do.

The new operators repainted the surfaces and added some fixtures so the atmosphere is now pleasant and casual; but it won't be earning any design awards soon.

The food is fine but not particularly interesting.  I had a pork chop that was nicely seasoned and with good sides but I am still trying to figure out why they paired the shrimp with mushrooms.  A salad we had was fine but a stewed pork was just dull.  I expected more from a cook who hails from Coco500.

The wine list is short and, except for a couple of interesting spanish wines, really uninspired (if I want to drink Columbia Crest I can buy it at any corner marker).  Maybe the drinks and tequila are interesting, but we never saw a drinks menu.

There were not very many people in the restaurant so my guess is that others who have tried it are similarly unethused.

SFD
author: Peter H.

description:
i ate dinner here for the first time yesterday after having walked right past it a zillion times.

i got shrimp in a spicy red sauce. it was pretty good!  also, they let you pick 2 sides with your entree, which is nice.  i enjoy having a choice about what my meal will consist of.  i ordered black beans and salad as my sides.  the beans were yummy, the salad just ok. 

the mariachi band started up around 9:30 pm and it was VERY loud.
author: Elle B.

description: Saturday night, post-my birthday bbq, pre-bicycle music fest. We want a power-up after all that Pabst, so we find the least-crowded place on 22nd. Huge space, decent energy for our $8 shots of Fernet that go down slimy syrupy -- I mean, the glass was fucking coated. I just drank Mrs. Butterworths.
author: Chris R.

description: So this place changed management a while back and has a more pedestrian menu and decor.  It's a good place for margaritas, but the characters behind the bar have changed and the food is more basic and affordable.
author: m.e. t.

description: I'm giving this place 5 stars because we got to witness history and celebrate with the coolest Missionites at last night's Obama victory.  I'm still pinching myself over the whole thing!  The big flat screen tvs on both sides of the bar rocked.  Our Bartender was attentive and friendly too.  The venue is spacious, clean, has comfy chairs and good food and drink (my malibu pinneapple was yummy and so were their guac/chips combo and french fries!).  If you like a fun atmosphere with good food, service and drink, then you will probably more than just like Cava 22!
author: Swetha G.

description: I had the empanadas with a friend, it wasn't great or bad. The most fun we had was putting money in the juke box.  I just wasn't excited enough to want to go back.
author: Cara J.

description: Like the others, I really wanted to like the place but it just misses the mark.  Yes, the service was friendly and gracious but bottom line, the food was just eh.  And the space, although large, is almost too large for the dining experience they are offering.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Tuesday night, we became their Revolution overflow. Chill place with chill Mexican music. We sat at the bar next to an El Salvadorean drunk (but friendly) dude who told us his nickname was FBI and just had drinks, and I decided this is one of the better places to have a Chimay...
author: Maximillian M.

description: It is becoming a tradition to end the sinco de mayo celebration here with my friends. A star for mariachis, a star for the food and a star for the very latin ambiance.
author: Liza A.

description: this place has potential to be sumtin gr8.  The service is amazing. If you look for Roger he can make any reasonable request possible and that is called good service.  They have a gr8 polenta stocks and their steak is very good too.  Their beet salad is ok.  Their duck is quite good and you must try the flourless chocolate cake and their homemade infused tequilas.
author: Mee-stique K.

description: The bartender asked if my friend wanted ginger ale or tonic with his "Gin and TONIC". My friend wasn't too impressed but since I am a tequila drinker, I had no issues... They have a HUGE selection of top shelf tequilas. MMmmm
author: Shauna B.

description:
I came to Cava 22 a few months ago.  We watched it's trasformation from the Bahia Club to Cava 22 with interest, and it seems like it hasn't really caught on yet.  I think the menu is pretty good, but there are so many good tapas restaurants within a 3-block radius that are as good and less expensive.  For example, Esperpento, Cha3, Limon Rotisserie, etc.  

What really annoyed me about this place is that there was a street barker (I think he may be the owner) who stood out in front goading you inside.  At least, the first month or two that was the case, and it was a real turnoff.  We actually avoided it at first because of it.  But then we thought we should give the restau a shot because it always looks so empty and forlorn, and the menu looked pretty good.  So we finally went and the dishes were rather tasty.  

We had the truffled raviolis, which are good but not really big enough to share, and the strip steak with fries.   I think we had some other things but their margaritas were good and probably contribute to my lack of memory.   I thought the portions were 20% too small and 20% too expensive.  But the drinks are wonderful.

I really want this restaurant to work out.  I think with some slight tweaks this resturant will really shine. 

And lose the barker.  Nobody likes the desperation...
author: Andrew M.

description: This place was super funnn...abit crowded but what do you expect on a friday nite. The drinks are yummy and the staff are super nice...did i mention they have Mariachis? yuup word on the street is that they are there on friday and saturday nites...just adds to the atmosphere...check it out
author: SASHA B.

description:
For the second time, my boyfriend and I were unable to get a table at Lolo.  It was pretty much empty and the hostess still said that it would be a 20 minute wait.  Why?  We even put down our name, gave a phone number and still did not receive a phone call ever.  So we went across the street to Cava 22.  The decor could use some work and it was soooo cold, but... The food was really good.  I was totally surprised.  My boyfriend actually used the words "pretty good", which he never says about food he hasn't made himself.  My ratatouille salad was excellent, he ate every bit of his skirt steak and the empanadas were good too.  
I don't know why people are giving this place such a low rating.  It's not crowded, the service is fine, and the food is really good.  Are we really that shallow that we have to be surrounded by douche bags to have a satisfying dinner?  
They do need to turn up the heat though.
author: Rebecca F.

description:
On a recent Friday night, when every bar/cafe/restaurant was overflowing with people (it was a rare balmy evening), we wandered into Cava 22 only to find it entirely empty.  Not a soul, save six somber staff members.  Instead of peppy Latin music, the dour new-age/classical music sounded like a funeral durge.  

The kind-faced hostess was stopping passers by, asking them to have a look at the menu, only to be consistently turned away.  We were killing time and sat at the bar for a beer, but the mood was killing us!  They all knew we were fishing the neighborhood for an open table, but we just couldn't sit alone in this den of desperation.  So we left.  

I knew nothing about this place, and I still cannot vouch for the food, but what on earth is wrong here?  At this rate, I give it another month, tops, before this restaurant says "adios"!
author: Meg M.

description: What's not to love? All the salty, spicey, greasey goodness while knocking back a couple drinks.
author: Jeff B.

description: Now this is what I'm talking about! Good drinks, tasty food, nice atmosphere and good looking chicas. Check it out if your in the Mission for nitelife.
author: Tom W.

description: Boy, do they have some work to do. We walked in here last night for a late night dinner. We were short on time so we told the host that we needed to be quick. We were told this wouldn't be a problem. 15 min later we're still waiting for some one to come take our drink order, bring us water, something! Finally a gentleman rushes over and we tell him we're in a hurry, can we order everything now. He takes our order, leaves, and then we don't see him for another 15 min. I have to flag down the host  to ask where our drinks are and can we please get some water? Finally the drinks show up, followed 2 min later by the food (at least the food came "on time"). Not that it was worth the wait; skip the empanadas and the pork all together - both were barely edible). The plantains were good but I would avoid the side sauce (a creamy side with chives and herbs - whose ever heard of such an accompaniment to plantains?!) The oysters were decent, along with the grilled rib eye, which was a good value. Overall the food was just ehhh at best. After we were thru eating, our server came over and apologized for the bad service and offered us a round of drinks on the house. At least they tried to make up for it some what. And the bill was pretty reasonable - 4 people with a round of drinks and 6 plates for less than $100... not really going to find that kind of value at many places, especially in the "hip" mission these days. So 1 star because we didn't drain our wallets on bad food and 1 star for the free drinks. If that's enough for you, then head on over. If not, then go to one of the hundred other mission eateries that seemed to have popped up every where.
author: Lisa W.

description: Tons of tequilas, extremely attentive and cordial staff, a fun mix of people, and plenty of space.  An easy place to relax, have a drink, do some people-watching, and continue through the Mission.
author: Josh J.

description: Our group of six ate here after seeing 'Tings dey Happen' at the nearby Marsh Theater. We were seated immediately.  Soon after that the busboy brought us a basket of chips and a bowl of salsa.  Warning: the Salsa is  somewhat hot and spicy.  You want to have some ice water handy before you dip.   We didn't and suffered for it.  We ordered a pitcher of margaritas to start.  They took a little too long to bring the drinks and water, otherwise the service was top notch.  For dinner I ordered the Seafood Paella.  Someone else ordered the Red Snapper and got the whole fish, head and tail included.  Fajitas were ordered, one beef  the other chicken.  Everyone said they really liked their food and drink.  The waitress was friendly, efficient and very dignified.  At one point the jukebox got too loud but the staff rushed to remedy the situation.  There was no Mariachi band that night but I saw that as a blessing since we had just done the audience thing for two hours at the Marsh and really just wanted to talk and interact with each other.  In the middle of our dinner some guy in costume wandered into the restaurant carrying a guitar.  Although the digital jukebox was playing he sat on a stool in the middle of the room noodling quietly on his axe.  I was worried that he would walk up to our table and serenade us but that never happened.  Next time I looked up he was gone.  For SF this restaurant is very reasonably priced.  I would come here again and recommend it to my friends.  Parking is difficult/expensive but there is a BART station not too far away.  After dinner as we were walking to the parking garage on 21st  Street a homeless guy with a shopping cart stepped in front of the six of us and asked for 75 cents.  Two of the women started digging in their purses while one of men shook his head and stated firmly,"It's going straight for booze!  Straight to booze!"  All in all a very San Francisco experience.
author: Tom M.

description: great food and enviroment! a bit pricey but worth it!
author: pablo e.

description:
My friend and I went there last night to try out the food after reading the description of the rest as offering Latino-Euro fusion items.  We got there around 6PM on a Monday, and the place is almost empty.  The only bartender is also the only waiter (till about 7 PM).  Since most of everyone sits at the bar, we kindda have to wait for services to drink and everything else.
We had a certificate from restaurant.com which stated it is valid if you order more than $35 or more.  After the waiter checked with the owner, he informed us that the term has changed and we have to order more than $50 to use the certificate.  I found that to be very odd as the terms are stated on the certificate, but not a big deal.  We proceed to order the short ribs and the seafood paella.  The paella was great, and the short ribs were good, but the mushroom that came as the dish of the short ribs were a little plain.  
I did enjoy the drinks very much, but the after dinner dessert was definitely a disappointment.  I wanted the flan, and it came looking like the surface of the moon.  With lots of holes and tasted dense and plain.
Because of the $25 off, we had a good meal at a reasonable price, but otherwise I think their food is overpriced for the quality.
I would recommend for drinks, especially if you like tequilla.
author: Cynthia C.

description: this joint is cool for goign wit co- workers after work the teq. shots are hugh here and cheap live mexican music check it out
author: Pedro V.

description: great food! good drinks! great for parties! great food and drinks! oops did i say that already? lol attended an anniversary party there and it was wonderful!
author: Marian F.
